thread.title: Barclays’s Michael Rake Said to Leave Board, Join WorldPay
thread.title_full: Barclays’s Michael Rake Said to Leave Board, Join WorldPay - Bloomberg Business

author: Stephen Morris
title: Barclays’s Michael Rake Said to Leave Board, Join WorldPay
text:
Barclays Plc’s Deputy Chairman Michael Rake will step down from the board to join payment operator WorldPay Ltd., after helping fire Chief Executive Officer Antony Jenkins, a person with knowledge of the situation said.
Rake, 67, who was also Barclays’s senior independent director, will join WorldPay as chairman as the private-equity-owned company prepares for an initial public offering, said the person, who asked not to be identified because Rake hasn’t resigned yet.
Rake was instrumental in the ouster of former-CEO Jenkins, who was fired after a clash with Tom King, head of Barclays’s investment bank, over the speed and depth of cuts to the securities unit, people familiar said. Chairman John McFarlane, 68, who took over as acting CEO, said the bank has become “cumbersome and bureaucratic” under Jenkins’s leadership.
Will Bowen, a spokesman at Barclays in London, declined to comment on the departure. Officials at WorldPay didn’t immediately respond to calls seeking comment. Sky News reported the departure earlier, saying Rake will replace John Allan as chairman of WorldPay in September.
Barclays Shares At Barclays, McFarlane told staff last week that he aims to double the share price over the next three years, or four years at most, according to people familiar. The lender may only appoint a new CEO early next year, the people said.
WorldPay, which is owned by Advent International Corp. and Bain Capital, is preparing a 6 billion-pound ($9.4 billion) IPO, according to Sky News. The owners may also decide to sell the payment processing group to other private-equity firms or a bank instead of selling shares, according to the reports.
Rake, who is also chairman of BT Group Plc, joined Barclays in 2008 after a 30 year career at KPMG, according to the bank’s website. He was named senior independent director in 2011 and deputy chairman a year later. He is also president of the Confederation of British Industry.
The shares were little changed at 276.30 pence at 9:54 a.m. in London. They increased every day since Jenkins was ousted a week ago, bringing gains to about 13 percent this year.
